foliation.p: Modern pencil foliation in Arabic numerals on the upper right corner of each recto folio.

collation.p: Approximately 15 sections, 4 bifolios per section, first and last section are a single bifolio, the last section is sewn with a full length stay of parchment to support the sewing as the main bifolio appears thinner and weaker than the rest of the book block.

layout.p: Folios have been pricked and scored to assist in writing.

handNote.p: Written in a Ge'ez script, in black and red ink, by a single hand.

additions.p: Coloured threads have been inserted in the margins of the folios marking the beginning of the praises for each day of the week; partly missing.
Medico-magical incantations against malarial fever, charms, syphilis on 1v-2r. Amharic. Different hands.
A list on 2r. Beginning: ጊዮርጊስ ፡ ማ ፡ ዘወልድ ፡ [ዋ ፡] ፀጋ ፡ መስቀል ፡ ማ ፡ ከንፍቅ ፡ ተክሉ ፡ አበ(s) [ዋ∫ ክፍሉይ ፡ ንፍቅ ፡ አባ ፡ ክብረ ፡ ኢየሱስ ፡ አባ ፡ ድልበ[፡]ኢየሱስ ፡ ማ ፡ ፪ማ ፡ ፊለታዎስ ፡ ዋ ፡ ስነ ፡ ጊዮርጊስ ፡ ...

Magical prayers for the expulsion of the placenta (በስመ ፡ አብ ፡ ክቡር ፡ ከፍል ፡ ፍልፍያኖስ ፡ መልዮስ ፡ ... እንግዴኸ ፡ ልጅ ፡ ይጻእ ፡...) and against vaginal hemorrhage (ሊስ፡ አፍሊስ ፡ ... በዝንቱ ፡ ስምከ ፡ ... ኢታሕምም ፡ ሥጋሃ ፡ ወኢታውፅእ ፡ ደመ ፡ አባላ ፡ ለአመትከ ፡ ...) on 139v-140r.
Two incantations against pestilence in Amharic (የሸነፈር : [sic]) on 140v.
At the top on 140v, a text of ten lines has been erased. A later addition was added, beginning with a magical prayer: አሕያ ፡ ሸራሕያ ፡ አልሳዳይ ፡ …

binding.decoNote: Ethiopic binding. The binding is/was full bound in dark reddish-brown leather with blind tooled decoration. The covering leather appears to have degraded at some point and as part of the repair process either the boards were transposed or the leather was lifted and relaid, as evidenced by the crucifix decoration on the boards being upside down. Turn-ins extend to frame a window on the inner boards that is lined with a thin woven textile, made up of stripes in blue, red, and yellow. There was likely an added strip to complete the framing on the spine facing edge, as evidenced by the change in discolouration to the textile. The repaired leather spine strip has thread connecting the turn-ins at the head and tail. It appears to have been linked to the sewing structure where it finishes in the wooden board. The spine leather has been repaired with a strip overlapping remnants of the original. This has the endband tie-downs through it which adds an additional means of attaching the boards to the structure. Brown leather split braid endbands appear to have been re-attached with the repair. There is a loss to the braided leather on the head band, towards the middle, but the sewing remains intact, and the tailband has slipped down the spine. Unsupported sewing at 4 stations (two even pairs of sewing stations). The sewing is laced into the boards as an integral part of the sewing process and is done in separate pairs with each pair sewn using a different thread.

Satchel made from one piece of leather; the base, sides and front edges are stitched together to complete the shape and the back panel extends up and over as a flap, now detached but kept with the case. A leather strap is made up of two pieces knotted together to form a loop. It appears that previously at least three strap loops were stitched to the main satchel with leather thongs but only one remains. 187 200 70

history.provenance: Marginalia on 139r indicates the book may have belonged to a church of St. George (ዘጊዮርጊስ ፡).

provenance.p: The name of the first owner has been erased wherever it occurs. The name of a second owner is mentioned on 128v: Atǝntä Dǝngǝl; a third name Zä-Wäldä Maryam on 117v.

James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847-1913) . The inner upper cover bears the armorial bookplate (Ex Libris) identifying the codex as having once been part of the Bibliotheca Lindesiana, the private library of the Lindsay family, Earls of Crawford and Balcarres | Armorial bookplate (Ex Libris): ARMS: Quarterly, 1st and 4th, Gules a fess chequy Argent and Azure; 2nd and 3rd, Or a lion rampant Gules, debruised of a ribbon in bend Sable. CREST: a swan’s head, neck, and wings proper, issuing from an antique ducal coronet Or. SUPPORTERS: two lions, rampant guardant Gules. MOTTO in Latin: Endure fort (Endure bravely) | Bibliotheca Lindesiana | pencilled: 5/G. Pencilled on left inner upper cover: Ethiopic MSS | No 24.
Purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847-1913).
